Company: Community Health Systems Professional Services Corporation
Description: Community Health Systems Professional Services Corporation and three affiliated New Mexico hospitals agreed to pay the United States $75 million to settle allegations that they violated the False Claims Act by making illegal donations to county governments which were used to fund the state share of Medicaid payments to the hospitals.
Agency: Justice Department Civil Division
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/community-health-systems-professional-services-corporation-and-three-affiliated-new-mexico

Description: Community Health Systems agreed to pay $31 million to resolve allegations that it submitted false claims for reimbursement to Medicare, Medicaid, and TRICARE, the Defense Department's health care program.
Agency: Justice Department Civil Division
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/archive/opa/pr/2000/May/096civ.htm

Description: The Justice Department announced that 16 separate hospitals and their respective corporate parents agreed to collectively pay $15.69 million to resolve False Claims Act allegations that the providers sought and received reimbursement from Medicare for mental health services that were not medically reasonable or necessary.
Agency: Justice Department Civil Division
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/sixteen-hospitals-pay-1569-million-resolve-false-claims-act-allegations-involving-medically

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: Community Health Systems Inc. agreed to pay $98.15 million to resolve multiple lawsuits alleging that the company knowingly billed government health care programs for inpatient services that should have been billed as outpatient or observation services. The settlement also resolved allegations that one of the company's affiliated hospitals, Laredo Medical Center, improperly billed the Medicare program for certain inpatient procedures and for services rendered to patients referred in violation of the Physician Self-Referral Law, commonly known as the Stark Law.
Agency: Justice Department Civil Division
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/community-health-systems-inc-pay-9815-million-resolve-false-claims-act-allegations

Description: The Department of Justice reached 70 settlements involving 457 hospitals in 43 states for more than $250 million related to cardiac devices that were implanted in Medicare patients in violation of Medicare coverage requirements.
Agency: Justice Department Civil Division
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/nearly-500-hospitals-pay-united-states-more-250-million-resolve-false-claims-act-allegations

Description: Health Management Associates, LLC, formerly a U.S. hospital chain headquartered in Naples, Florida, agreed to pay more than $260 million to resolve criminal charges and civil claims relating to a scheme to defraud the United States. The government alleged that HMA knowingly billed government health care programs for inpatient services that should have been billed as outpatient or observation services, paid remuneration to physicians in return for patient referrals, and submitted inflated claims for emergency department facility fees. HMA entered into a three-year non-prosecution agreement while one of its subsidiaries pled guilty to one count of conspiracy to commit healthcare fraud.
Agency: Justice Department Civil Division
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/hospital-chain-will-pay-over-260-million-resolve-false-billing-and-kickback-allegations-one

Description: On November 7, 2016, Metro Knoxville HMA, LLC (Metro Knoxville), in Knoxville, Tennessee, entered into a $45,000 settlement agreement with OIG. The settlement agreement resolves allegations that Metro Knoxville violated the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act when it discharged a patient without having provided an adequate medical screening examination or treatment sufficient to stabilize the patient.
Agency: Health & Human Services Department Office of Inspector General
Info Source: https://oig.hhs.gov/fraud/enforcement/cmp/cmp-ae.asp

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
NAICS Translation: 423450: Medical, Dental, and Hospital Equipment and Supplies Merchant Wholesalers
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Agency: U.S. Attorney-Western District of New York
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/usao-wdny/pr/32-hospitals-pay-us-more-28-million-resolve-false-claims-act-allegations-related

Description: Dyersburg Hospital Company, LLC d/b/a Dyersburg Regional Medical Center entered into a $45,000 settlement agreement with OIG resolving allegations that it violated the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act when it failed to provide an appropriate medical screening examination and stabilizing treatment to a patient who presented to its Emergency Department.
Agency: Health & Human Services Department Office of Inspector General
Info Source: https://oig.hhs.gov/fraud/enforcement/cmp/cmp-ae.asp

Description: Community Health Systems agreed to pay $31 million to Illinois, New Mexico, South Carolina, Tennessee, Texas and West Virginia as well as the federal government to resolve false claims allegations related to upcoding in reimbursement requests submitted to government health programs. The settlement was also announced by the Justice Department; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-community-health-systems-0
Agency: Multistate Attorneys General Case
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/archive/opa/pr/2000/May/096civ.htm

Company: Health Management Associates, Inc. and Clearview Regional Medical Center
Description: Health Management Associates, Inc. and Clearview Regional Medical Center agreed to jointly pay $396,770 in settlement of allegations they submitted false claims to the Georgia Medicaid program.
Agency: Georgia Attorney General
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20190422183724/https://law.georgia.gov/press-releases/2015-06-04/attorney-general-olens-announces-settlement-health-management-and

Description: Health Management Associates agreed to pay $706,084 to settle multistate litigation alleging that it caused false claims to be submitted to state Medicaid programs as the result of a practices such as billing for inpatient services that should have been coded as outpatient or observation services, paying remuneration to physicians in return for patient referrals, and submitting inflated claims for emergency department facility fees. This was part of a larger $260 million settlement involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-health-management-associates-llc
Agency: Multistate Attorneys General Case
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/hospital-chain-will-pay-over-260-million-resolve-false-billing-and-kickback-allegations-one

Agency: Florida Attorney General

Agency: Multistate Attorneys General Case
